p: The antioxidant activity of thyme has been demonstrated through several in vitro and in vivo methods. Using in vitro methods, Aouam et al. [ 42] reported that Thymus riatarum showed a high DPPH radical-scavenging capacity and ferric reducing power in ethanolic, aqueous and methanolic extracts. In addition, Golkar et al. [ 43] showed the cytotoxic activities of phenolic compounds in the essential oil of thyme by using a phosphomolybdate assay.
